articles.headline: U.S. Budget Deal in Doubt; Obama’s Trip to Hill Reveals Split
articles.snippet: The president’s meeting with House Republicans served only to reinforce the divisions that have created a cycle of deadline-driven short-term fiscal policy.
articles.abstract: The president’s meeting with House Republicans served only to reinforce the divisions that have created a cycle of deadline-driven short-term fiscal policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s meeting with a restive and resistant House Republican majority on Wednesday underscored their deep divisions over fiscal policy as both sides acknowledged that an overarching budget compromise was in doubt despite a new push by the White House.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: TiVo Goes Wandering, on the Road and at Home
articles.snippet: Two new accessories allow you to both time-shift and place-shift your TiVo: the TiVo Mini and the TiVo Stream.
articles.abstract: Two new accessories allow you to both time-shift and place-shift your TiVo: the TiVo Mini and the TiVo Stream.
articles.lead_paragraph: You always remember the days that changed your life forever. Your first kiss. The birth of a child. The day you got a TiVo.

articles.headline: A Conservative With a Common Touch
articles.snippet: Jorge Mario Bergoglio, 76, to be called Francis, will break ground as a Jesuit and Latin American. But his views on gay marriage, abortion and other issues make him a conservative choice to lead the church.
articles.abstract: Jorge Mario Bergoglio, 76, to be called Francis, will break ground as a Jesuit and Latin American. But his views on gay marriage, abortion and other issues make him a conservative choice to lead the church.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Like most of those in Argentina, he is a soccer fan, his favorite team being the underdog San Lorenzo squad. Known for his outreach to the country’s poor, he gave up a palace for a small apartment, rode public transportation instead of a chauffeur-driven car and cooked his own meals.
articles.byline: By Emily Schmall and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: Spinoff of Time Inc. Rattles Employees
articles.snippet: After the split occurs, Time Inc. will no longer have the lucrative film and television assets of Time Warner to prop it up.
articles.abstract: After the split occurs, Time Inc. will no longer have the lucrative film and television assets of Time Warner to prop it up.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was an elite reception at a glittery Manhattan setting: prominent media figures like Gayle King and Lesley Stahl gathered on the 10th floor of the Time Warner Center on Monday night to toast Sheryl Sandberg, the Facebook executive who recently released a book about her life.

articles.headline: New Pope Shifts Church’s Center of Gravity Away From Europe
articles.snippet: The selection of an Argentine, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, as pope served as an emphatic salute to the growing power of Latinos across the Americas.
articles.abstract: The selection of an Argentine, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, as pope served as an emphatic salute to the growing power of Latinos across the Americas.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The surprise selection on Wednesday of an Argentine, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, as the new pope shifted the gravity of the Roman Catholic Church from Europe to Latin America in one fell swoop, and served as an emphatic salute to the growing power of Latinos across the Americas.

articles.headline: At NBC, a Struggle to Revive the Morning Magic
articles.snippet: The last year for Matt Lauer, the once-popular host of the network’s “Today” show, is a lesson on how a combination of missteps can precipitate a star’s fall.
articles.abstract: The last year for Matt Lauer, the once-popular host of the network’s “Today” show, is a lesson on how a combination of missteps can precipitate a star’s fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staff members at NBC’s “Today” show huddled for a performance review last month, 10 months after the longtime morning show leader first fell behind ABC’s “Good Morning America” in the ratings. The mood was anxious, according to several attendees, as network executives discussed the findings from focus groups with hundreds of viewers.

articles.headline: Horse Meat Applicant’s Food Safety Is Questioned
articles.snippet: The New Mexico company, Valley Meat, drew complaints over a two-year period from federal inspectors and state regulators over its disposal of remains when it processed cattle for beef.
articles.abstract: The New Mexico company, Valley Meat, drew complaints over a two-year period from federal inspectors and state regulators over its disposal of remains when it processed cattle for beef.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New Mexico company seeking to become the first slaughter house for horses in the United States since 2007 drew complaints over a two-year period from federal food safety inspectors and state regulatory authorities over its disposal of animal remains when it processed cattle for beef.

articles.headline: Cities Weigh Taking Over From Private Utilities
articles.snippet: Municipalities are showing an interest in creating their own utilities, reflecting concerns about climate change and responses to power disruptions.
articles.abstract: Municipalities are showing an interest in creating their own utilities, reflecting concerns about climate change and responses to power disruptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Across the country, cities are showing a renewed interest in taking over the electricity business from private utilities, reflecting intensifying concerns about climate change, responses to power disruptions and a desire to pump more renewable energy into the grid.

articles.headline: Initial Tests of Battery by Boeing Fell Short
articles.snippet: Evaluations that Boeing conducted while the the 787 jet was in development proved to be far off the mark in predicting what would happen when the plane was in use.
articles.abstract: Evaluations that Boeing conducted while the the 787 jet was in development proved to be far off the mark in predicting what would happen when the plane was in use.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an age of sophisticated computer modeling, Boeing engineers relied on the same test used for tiny cellphone batteries to gather data about the safety of the heftier lithium-ion battery on its new 787 jets: they drove a nail into it to see what happened.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Google Hastens to Show Its Concern for Privacy
articles.snippet: Google executives are realizing that penalties for privacy breaches, like those it acknowledged involving its Street View project, do matter, if only because of the reputational risks.
articles.abstract: Google executives are realizing that penalties for privacy breaches, like those it acknowledged involving its Street View project, do matter, if only because of the reputational risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley hates being told what to do. “Better to seek forgiveness than permission” is its unofficial slogan.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Entrenched Troubles at Vatican Await a New Pope
articles.snippet: The choice of a New World pope sent messages about the Roman Catholic Church: that its future lies in the global south and that a scholar with a common touch may inspire its faithful.
articles.abstract: The choice of a New World pope sent messages about the Roman Catholic Church: that its future lies in the global south and that a scholar with a common touch may inspire its faithful.
articles.lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — By choosing the first pope from the New World, the cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church sent a strong message of change: that the future of the church lies in the global south, and that a scholar with a common touch may be its best choice to inspire the faithful.
